title: This Morning's Eamonn Holmes and Ruth Langsford clash on smacking ban
text:
This Morning's Eamonn Holmes and his co-presenter and wife Ruth Langsford clashed on-screen during a debate about the ban on smacking children in Scotland.

The TV presenter, 59, explained during the debate that he was beaten when he was a child at school which appeared to lead to dispute between the duo.

Ruth and Eamonn were debating with their guests whether parents should be banned from smacking their children in England, after Scotland became the first UK country to ban it.

Spat: This Morning's Eamonn Holmes and his co-presenter and wife Ruth Langsford clashed on-screen during a debate about the ban on smacking children in Scotland

Offering his opinion as to whether smacking affects children in later life, Eamonn said: 'We were beaten at school...

However Ruth appeared to take umbrage with the word 'beaten' and said: 'You say beaten... this language'.

But Eamonn continued: 'I'm telling you, taking a complete leather strap [gestures to his wrist] for not backing your homework book.'

Debate: The TV presenter, 59, explained during the debate that he was beaten when he was a child at school which appeared to lead to dispute between the duo

While explaining, Ruth attempted to cut in and say: 'No I'm just saying...'

Journalist Clare Muldoon who believes smacking children does no harm, then said:' That was right to be banned, proper punishment in schools is right to be banned.

Ruth agreed, and said: 'I don't like that.'

Attempting to explain his view, Eamonn said: 'My point about school is that I look back at that now and Ruth's like "oh that couldn't have happened that's like Victorian'.

Disagree: Ruth and Eamonn were debating with their guests whether parents should be banned from smacking their children in England, after Scotland became the first UK country to ban it

However visibly annoyed, Ruth replied: 'I wasn't saying that!'

The duo soon breezed over their brief dispute and continued their segment.

MSPs voted to outlaw parents using physical punishment on their children by 84 votes to 29 after a bill was introduced by Scottish Greens MSP John Finnie.

The move has brought Scotland up to international standards, with Mr Finnie arguing: 'Physical punishment has no place in 21st century'.

Opinion: Offering his opinion as to whether smacking affects children in later life, Eamonn said: 'We were beaten at school...'

Previously parents and carers are allowed to use 'reasonable' physical force in order to discipline children.

But the law change is aimed at giving children the same protection from assault as adults and stops them from doing so.

The bill was passed at the Scottish Government on Thursday, despite a YouGov poll of 1,546 adults from across the UK which suggested 57 per cent oppose the move.
description: This Morning's Eamonn Holmes and his co-presenter and wife Ruth Langsford clashed on-screen during a debate about the ban on smacking children in Scotland.
